What a shame that a really competent director like Andre de Toth who specialized in slippery, shifting alliances didn't get hold of this concept first. He could have gotten similarly dramatic, climactic results while also letting his main character cover more ground by shifting the focus to his loyalty and reliability than on family strife. Still, it is a decent gangster yarn with lots of highs and lows.

The only reason I am commenting is because I finally figured out why Dr. Cox was bald. Although we probably all realized it at the same time this week Dr. Cox is bald because he has Raynaud's syndrome. If you look carefully every time he is disgusted, annoyed, or stressed you can see his finger tips go white. The Bone Snatcher is about a group miners who go on a search for a missing crew of miners in the Namib Desert. When the find them, the crew are found in an area with spikes with feeding tubes going all over the place and several skeletons and bodies half eaten. So what are they living with and more importantly who or what is killing them? Snow White is in my opinion a bad movie on an artistic point of view. The plot is pretty much foreseeable, the characters are stereotypes, the editing too. The movie is pale by comparison to more recent Disney fairy tales, thanks to computer graphics. The biggest mistake to my point of view is a pretty traditional one, with regards to aesthetics, the lack of exposure of the main characters nudity. What is left of Planet Earth is populated by a few poor and starving rag-tag survivors. They must eat bugs and insects, or whatever they can find. The wealthy live in the mountains, under the protection of a robot called Ram. They have all the wealth of the world, brilliant architecture and beautiful gardens. The poor are allowed to visit the mountains on infrequent occasions, so that they may showcase a new invention, a sort of potato on a stick
